awd_titl_txt: Contrasting active magma- and fault-dominated segments of the East African Rift through the synthesis of InSAR and GPS time series: Implications for rifting dynamics and hazards
awd_abstract_narration:
The East Africa Rift System (EARS) produces large damaging earthquakes, landslides, and volcanic hazards that threaten large developing populations that tend to be relatively less well-prepared with resilient infrastructure. Measuring how the surface of the Earth deforms in response to these natural processes allows scientists to better understand them and the associated hazards. The Global Positioning System (GPS) network in Africa is sparse, and network expansion has both political and financial challenges. Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) greatly complements GPS measurements with high spatial and temporal resolution imagery of ground deformation over the entire EARS, while avoiding the complications and costs associated with installing and maintaining instrumentation. Beyond volcano and tectonic applications, combining GPS and InSAR measurements of ground deformation also allows scientists to monitor anthropogenic activities such as groundwater extraction. Understanding both natural and anthropogenic-related deformation is important for local communities for better water management, improved planning and development of infrastructure, and protection of natural environments.

The objective of this project is to produce precise maps of temporally and spatially dense crustal deformation time series across the central EARS documenting tectonic, volcanic, and anthropogenic related deformation signals.  This will involve synthesizing and integrating GPS data collected by previously funded GeoPRISMS projects with InSAR displacement time series across the central section of the EARS. These data will allow for improved characterization and comparisons of distributions of strain between the likely plume-controlled eastern segment and the likely fault-controlled western segment that branches around the Tanzania Craton, placing these observations in the context of the geologic history and pre-existing structures. Results from this work will provide reliable measurements of crustal deformation to support a diverse range of research questions related to rift dynamics. Additionally, it will provide critical constraints for modeling rift initiation and evolution on the central, eastern, and western segments of the EARS, with extended applications to anthropogenic deformation

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The East African Rift System (EARS) is an active continental rift zone that hosts a diverse range of processes leading to recent and ongoing crustal deformation. To gain a more comprehensive understanding of these processes, we used Sentinel-1a/b InSAR data to complement the sparse Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) velocity field, providing high resolution measurements of line-of-sight deformation between 2015 and 2022. This was in line with the goals for the final year of the GeoPRISMS program and the overarching goal of this project, which was focussed on synthesis and integration of large datasets covering the EARS.

 

The EARS produces damaging earthquakes, landslides, and volcanic hazards that threaten large developing populations that tend to be relatively less prepared with resilient infrastructure. Satellite-based observations provide an excellent resource for scientists to study the evolution of deformation and the associated hazards along the EARS while avoiding the complications and costs associated with installing and maintaining instrumentation on site. Beyond better characterizing these geophysical processes, a secondary aim of the project is to document and characterize geodetic signals related to anthropogenic activities such as groundwater extraction. Much of the area is prone to drought, and large populations depend on groundwater resources for agriculture and potable water. Our results shed light on deformation associated with over-extraction of groundwater, and are important for local communities for better groundwater management, improved planning, and development of infrastructure and protection of natural environments.

 

A broad survey approach was employed to detect new signals within the central section of the EARS and to establish a baseline for future studies targeting tectonic, volcanic, and/or hydrological deformation over the last decade. The data products enabled us to pinpoint signals with spatial extents of 100s of meters to 100s of kilometers, varying from a few weeks to several years for signals with magnitudes as small as 5-10 mm/yr. The resulting deformation field illuminates a variety of signals attributed to tectonic, volcanic, and anthropogenic related deformation signals, some of which reach over 8 cm/yr . Among the deformation we measured was significant groundwater-related subsidence in Nairobi, Kenya, large displacements and likely precursory signals associated with the eruption of Nyiragongo in 2021 located in the Virunga region, as well as localized uplift in the Manyara basin in Tanzania. Additionally, we updated previously known deformation signals such as uplift of Mount Suswa volcano in Kenya and widespread, sustained subsidence of the geothermal fields in Olkaria in Tanzania. We measured tectonic-related deformation across the Kenya Rift, with the most pronounced differential rates occurring near Lake Turkana.

 

The GNSS network in this region is very sparse, and network expansion is faced with both political and financial challenges. InSAR greatly complements GPS measurements, offering high spatial and temporal resolution across the entire EARS, documenting not just tectonic and volcanic activities but also anthropogenic-related deformations, including groundwater extraction. GNSS measurements, on the other hand, offer more reliable 3D constraints of long wavelength deformation and were used to reference the InSAR velocity field. Our results underline the limitation and ambiguity of exclusively relying on the sparse network of GNSS for studies, particularly those examining tectonic motion and rift opening. There is potential that such studies might overlook significant signals or include sites contaminated with extraneous signals unrelated to the main investigation.

 

This GeoPRISMS postdoctoral award supported the professional development of an early career scientist by facilitating new research directions, mentorship, and collaboration. In addition, we leveraged  the University of Hawaii Manoa’s NSF-funded Geoscience Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program to develop projects to which talented underrepresented undergraduate students were able to gain valuable research experience.  Finally, this project supported the development of data processing techniques and open source software development and open data access.
